greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Let p1 <= p2 <= ... <= pk be the prime factors of n, with repetition; let s = 1/p1 + 1/(p1*p2) + 1/(p1*p2*p3) + ... + 1/(p1*p2*...*pk); a(n) = numerator of s. a(1)=0 by convention.
comment: Note that s < 1 for all n (compare A322036). This follows easily by induction, since when we increase n by multiplying it by a new (not-smaller) prime, we increase s by less than 1-s.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..16384
Antti Karttunen, Data supplement: n, a(n) computed for n = 1..65537
example: If n=12 we get the prime factors 2,2,3, and s = 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/12 = 5/6. So a(12) = 5.
maple: # This generates the terms starting at n=2:
P:=proc(n) local FM: FM:=ifactors(n)[2]: seq(seq(FM[j][1], k=1..FM[j][2]), j=1..nops(FM)) end: # A027746
for i from 1 to nops(t1) do b:=b/t1[i]; a:=a+b; od;
program: (PARI) A322034(n) = if(1==n,0,my(f=factor(n),pm=1,s=0); for(i=1,#f~,while(f[i,2],pm *= f[i,1]; f[i,2]--; s += 1/pm)); numerator(s)); \\ _Antti Karttunen_, Feb 28 2019
xref: A017665/A017666 = sum of reciprocals of all divisors of n.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_ and _David James Sycamore_, Nov 28 2018
